column1: Atotonilco El Alto is a town and municipality
column2: in Jalisco in Los Altos (Jalisco) region in central-western Mexico. The municipality covers an area of 638.15 km2.

column1: Atotonilco (pronounced ah-toh-toh-NEAL-co) means "place of hot waters"
column2: in Náhuatl. "El Alto"("The High One") was later added in honor of those who died in the Cristero War in the early 1920s.
the municipality had a total population of 51

column1: The town was first established by the Purépecha in late 1400
column2: according to Purépecha myth. The region was conquered in June 1530 by the Nuño de Guzmán. Martin del Campo was the first encomendero and the evangelization of the region was entrusted to the Franciscans. Atotonilco in 1551 was given in encomienda to the conquistador Andrés de Villanueva. In November 1824 the State Congress ruled that the village of Atotonilco hereafter would have the title of town
column3: and would also be the head of the department which includes Arandas and Ayotlán. On May 15
column7: elevated the status of Atotonilco to a city
column8: which it retains to this day.

column2: Taretan Water Park started functioning as a natural hot spring bath and an amusement place for families located at the sides of the Taretan River. Taretan was founded in the highlands of Jalisco. It was remodeled in the mid-1920s and now it houses a stone statue of St. Michael Archangel the Patron Saint of Atotonilco. It also has several sheds with tables and chairs made out of stone
column4: and a playground for young children to play. This park is mostly known for its waters. Hispanic legend of this place claims that the waters in Taretan have healing properties.

column1: Venerable Maria Luisa de la Peña
column2: Mexican Roman Catholic nun and founder of the Carmelite Sisters of the Most Sacred Heart of Los Angeles
Bishop of San Juan de los Lagos

column1: General Enrique Gorostieta was killed there during the Cristero War.
